content.title: Brachial Artery Anatomy
content.description: Main artery of the arm, continuation of axillary artery from lower border of teres major to its bifurcation in the cubital fossa into radial and ulnar arteries.
content.course: Runs along medial side of upper arm, becomes more superficial as it descends, crosses anterior to elbow

boundaries.distal: Bifurcation in cubital fossa, 1cm distal to elbow crease

branches.profunda_brachii: Largest branch, accompanies radial nerve in spiral groove

relations.median_nerve: Crosses from lateral to medial (forms an 'X' with artery)

clinical_applications.blood_pressure: Standard site for auscultatory BP measurement

content.termination: Bifurcates into radial and ulnar arteries in cubital fossa
content.statement: Brachial Artery Anatomy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Anatomy Upper-Extremity that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Brachial Artery Anatomy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Brachial Artery Anatomy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Brachial Artery Anatomy.

citations.source: UpToDate. (2024). Brachial Artery Anatomy. Wolters Kluwer.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
